What I Learned from Meditating Every Day for a Year

Alex Williamson
Mar 22

My meditation journey started fifteen years ago. I studied Western philosophy at university. This lead to a deep interest in Eastern thought. Subsequent travels throughout India and South East Asia brought me in contact with the practice of meditation. The stars had aligned and I was hooked. I took a typically Western empirical approach, devouring Buddhist and Hindu texts on philosophy and meditation in a bid to gain an intellectual understanding, with the intention to eventually put theory into practice

My plan was to sit and meditate for hours on end, with the goal of becoming enlightened. What a naïve ambition that was! As a consequence I never ended up sticking with my meditation practice. I would have great weeks, with perceived breakthroughs, and then I’d miss a few days, or weeks… and then I was back to square one. This went on for a decade. I did learn a lot and I believe I did benefit from my stop start practice. But I never felt comfortable that I was getting the most I could from meditation.

This all changed when I came across an article detailing a study by Zoran Josipovic of New York University[1]. The study examined how meditation altered our brain waves, and could subsequently influence our immediate mental states and behaviours. What if I’d got it all wrong? Maybe I should lower my expectations, and commit to a realistic and consistent practice. Maybe I could reap some more immediate and tangible benefits before worrying about enlightenment!

So, that’s exactly what I did. At the beginning of 2018, I made a commitment to meditate for a minimum of fifteen minutes everyday to see where it would take me. I achieved my goal, and continue to meditate daily. It’s just become a regular part of my life. My practice involves simple breath awareness meditation, ending with with brief loving kindness meditation. I’ll usually do one session in the morning, and one in the evening. The results have been incredible. Here are the key things I learned from my experience.

Ability to Deal with Stress and Anxiety

By the time I was twenty-six years old, I was a husband, a father, and had started my first business. All things I am eternally grateful for, but a potent driver of strength for a young man still finding his way in the world. I suffered fairly consistently throughout my twenties. I grew into life in my thirties as I matured and things became more stable. But I was left with a nagging feeling of always needing to be “on”, striving, competing and succeeding.

Chronic stress can cause a wide array of physical and mental health issues[2]. I notably suffered from anxiety, a lack of focus, and sleep disorders. However, meditation has completely eradicated these issues. It has led to me being much more present and mindful. I am able to quickly catch rising stress, check it and flip back into “rest and relaxation” mode by centring myself and focusing on the breath. It’s a truly beautiful thing.

You might say this is a placebo effect, or related to other changes in my life (I have made dramatic improvements to my overall approach to life over recent years). Whether or not this is the case, there are a number of studies to support the assertion that a consistent meditation practice can act as a key driver of stress reduction[3][4]. It has also been shown that meditation may also help to reduce the symptoms of stress related physical and mental conditions[5].

Increased Emotional Health and Wellbeing

Due to my stress levels, a naturally very competitive nature, and a strong desire to succeed, I would say that I’ve not always been the most emotionally intelligent being. Sometimes closed off, often competitive, viewing my fellow humans as competition, rather than collaborators. Growing up and focusing on personal development has helped me a lot over the years, but meditation has been the real game changer on this front.

I feel much more connected to the world, and to other people. I’m less angry, less competitive, and kinder and more loving to my family, friends, colleagues and people I meet in day to day life .I have learned to see that we’re all on the same path with similar challenges. We work far better together, as opposed to buffeting against one another. Coming from a place of love and support, I have felt much better equipped to help both myself and others. And I have noticed that I have become much more approachable and made more friends this way.

I believe the loving kindness aspect of my practice has played a big role here. There are a number of studies support the supposition that loving meditation can induce positive thinking and optimism[6], and reduce anger[7] compassion for myself and others[8]. Studies also show that like many things in life the more effort you put in, the more you get out[9], and that these benefits consistently accumulate over time[10]. Just taking a few moments each day to focus on love and compassion for yourself and others is a big deal.

Improved Self-Awareness and Mindfulness

This leads to my next point. In the modern world we are constantly hit with a never ending stream of stimuli. We hardly ever have a moment to stop and think. We are conditioned to look to the future. We bounce from one thing to the next, chasing dreams that are just around the corner. And so we should. But, it is important to stay mindful of the present. Really that is all we have, and the journey is arguably more important than the destination.

I was guilty of ignoring this. I was always obsessing over the next big move for my business, or nearly having the amount of money I needed to do what I believed I wanted to do. All dreams of the future, little consideration for the beautiful life I have in the present moment, each and every day. Stopping to meditate and exist in the present on a daily basis really helps you connect to the present. On a moment to moment basis, I now feel much more self-aware of both my thoughts and my actions. I am far more capable of embracing, enjoying, and remaining grateful for each and every moment I experience.

A number of the studies already cited allude to some of the benefits of generating improved self-awareness and mindfulness. There are also specific studies showing how increased present moment awareness can deliver a range of benefits, including; subjective well-being, mental and emotional health, improved behavioural regulation[11], and more constructive thought patterns[12]. This certainly mirrors my own personal feelings.

Major Focus and Performance Gains

It is these improvements in thought patterns and behaviour that I would like to turn to next. I can certainly say that I’ve always been a very productive person. Juggling a lot of balls, but great with time management, and I get results. But at what cost! A few summers ago a friend of mine suggested I could achieve more by doing less. Making time for myself to recharge and to focus my energies on the areas where I could be most effective.

These comments really stuck with me, and meditation has helped me put them into action. It forces me to take time out for myself every single day. It’s a guaranteed pause to centre myself, de-clutter my mind, collect my thoughts and gain clarity. This enables me to approach everything I do with much more purpose and focus, which in turn leads to an increase in performance. I’m focusing on what needs to be done, and doing it to a higher standard, whilst cutting loose the things that are not important.

Yes, again there are studies in support of these opinions of mine. Apparently, as little as four consecutive days of meditation can improve cognition[13]. Again these benefits accumulate. Consistent meditation can help stop your mind wandering[14], enable sharper mental recall[15], help to refocus and maintain attention[16], and result in improved problem solving abilities[17].

Dramatic Improvements in Sleep Quality

Sleep has become a big part of my life in recent years. I used to pride myself on my ability to get by on five or six hours of sleep a night. As I’ve alluded to a few times, I was typically trying to cram a lot into my life. I saw it as a great bit of luck that I didn’t need much sleep. Or so I thought. What I didn’t realise was the toll it was taking on my physical and mental health. Once I got switched on to the importance of sleep for health, wellbeing and longevity, my attitude dramatically changed.

I recently wrote about why quality sleep is a challenge in the modern world, and what you can do to fix it. Mediation has definitely been a part of that mix. I’ll tend to do a session before bed which helps me to de-stress and minimise brain activity. I go to bed calm, relaxed and ready to sleep, helping me to fall asleep much quicker and follow healthy, natural sleep cycles (and I have the evidence to support this via my sleep tracker).

The studies also back this assertion. Meditation has been shown to help people fall asleep faster and stay asleep for longer[18], and can also help to minimise disturbances during sleep[19]. There is some evidence to suggest that meditation can also help with sleep disorders, such as insomnia[20]. Regardless of the science, I have found meditation a great help in relaxing, releasing tension and putting body and mind in a peaceful state that is conducive to quality sleep.

Obviously I’m excited about the improvements I’ve made in my life, and clearly I believe that meditation has played a major role in that. I have tried to be objective and share the research and studies underpinning some of my opinions. You could potentially argue that has created a placebo effect, or that this is all very subjective. I will leave it up to you to experiment yourself, and draw your own conclusions.

What I can say, is that I have received a lot of positive feedback from other people. Those close to me have said that I’ve become much warmer, more open and more approachable, and much less aggressive, and competitive. This has also reflected in the wider friendship groups I have recently developed over the last year or so. I seem to find it easier to speak and connect with people, and they to me. Not that I was a horrible person before (I think), but I’ve made improvements.

I’m also in the best shape of my life, and meditation has definitely played a role in that. Keeping me focused and mindful of what I’m doing and helping me build great habits around things such as nutrition, exercise and sleep. This focus has also helped with my career. It helped guide into selling off a business I wasn’t passionate about, and spending the time and money on another business I am far more passionate about, and that has far more potential.

I’m not putting this all of this down to meditation. However, I would say that it’s the solid rock on which I have built a foundation to build and excel across these other areas of my life. Many of you are probably reading this as you already have a regular meditation practice. Others may be new to meditation or just have a passing interest. Whatever your situation, I hope I have given you a few interesting insights into benefits of meditation that you may not have considered. I’d love to get an insight into your experiences. Does what I say match up with your experiences, or have you had a totally different experience with meditation?
